title: Home
text:
ì•„ë˜ëŠ” gptê°€ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ì¤€ ë‚´ ì†Œê°œ ëŒ€ë¬¸ì´ì•¼. ëª¨ë“  gptì— ì €ì¥ëœ ëª¨ë“  ë°ì´í„°ë¥¼ ê¸°ë°˜ìœ¼ë¡œ ë‚˜ë¥¼ ë§Œë“¤ì–´ ë‹¬ë¼ê³  í–ˆë”ë‹ˆ, ì•„ë˜ì²˜ëŸ¼ ì†Œê°œí•´ì¤¬ì–´!
1. I turn language into tools for growth.

2. I build systems of learning grounded in clarity and precision.

3. I believe action speaks louder than expertise alone.

4. I create educational content that moves people forward.

5. I write to illuminate ideas, not to decorate them.

6. I design learning experiences that are structured, deep, and intuitive.

7. I bridge theory and practice through relentless curiosity.

8. I teach to understand, and understand to empower.

9. I pursue creativity with discipline and purpose.

10. I live by the principle that growth becomes real only when knowledge becomes action.

title: Daily Thinking
text:
10 DAILY THINKINGS


Ten lines that capture how Seoyun thinks, learns, and moves.




01 Â· Picasso


â€œAction is the foundational key to all success.â€


Meaning: Success begins the moment you move, not when you finish planning.


Why it fits you: You constantly choose action over endless talking and overthinking.




02 Â· Benjamin Franklin


â€œWell done is better than well said.â€


Meaning: A finished piece of work is worth more than a perfectly explained idea.


Why it fits you: You are building a life where results quietly speak louder than words.




03 Â· Aristotle


â€œWe are what we repeatedly do.â€


Meaning: Habits define identity more than one-time achievements.


Why it fits you: Your teaching, writing, and coding all grow out of long-term routines.




04 Â· Henri Matisse


â€œCreativity takes courage.â€


Meaning: Creating something new always exposes your inner world.


Why it fits you: Poems, essays, textbooksâ€”each one is you choosing courage in public.




05 Â· Carol Dweck


â€œBecoming is better than being.â€


Meaning: The process of growing matters more than the label you have right now.


Why it fits you: You are more interested in your next version than in any fixed title.




06 Â· Joubert


â€œTo teach is to learn twice.â€


Meaning: Teaching forces you to rebuild knowledge from the inside out.


Why it fits you: As both student and teacher, you turn every lesson into double learning.




07 Â· Unknown


â€œClarity is the courage to be understood.â€


Meaning: Being clear means you are willing to be seen exactly as you are.


Why it fits you: Your grammar tables and materials always fight for clean structure.




08 Â· Earl Nightingale


â€œYou become what you think about.â€


Meaning: The thoughts you revisit are shaping your future self every day.


Why it fits you: Your deep self-analysis and reflection are part of how you design yourself.




09 Â· Van Gogh


â€œGreat things are done by a series of small things.â€


Meaning: Big outcomes are built from tiny, almost invisible pieces.


Why it fits you: Chunk lists, grammar tables, and steady content all live in this sentence.




10 Â· Gandhi


â€œThe future depends on what you do today.â€


Meaning: Tomorrow is not created somedayâ€”it is created tonight.


Why it fits you: Your daily study and writing routines are already funding your future self.

title: Jane Austen ìŠ¤íƒ€ì¼ ë¶„ì„
text: Jane Austenì˜ ê¸€ì€ N-gram ëª¨ë¸ë¡œ ë¶„ì„í•˜ë©´ì„œ, ìš°ë¦¬ëŠ” ì–¸ì–´ê°€ ë°˜ë³µì˜ ê·œì¹™ì„ ë”°ë¥¸ë‹¤ëŠ” ê²ƒì„ ë°°ì› ë‹¤. íŠ¹íˆ â€œI must confessâ€, â€œIt is certainâ€ ê°™ì€ í‘œí˜„ì´ ìì£¼ ë“±ì¥í–ˆëŠ”ë°, ì´ëŠ” ê°ì •ì˜ ëª…ë£Œí•œ í‘œí˜„ì´ë‚˜ ìê¸° ì£¼ì¥ì„ ë‚˜íƒ€ë‚¼ ë•Œ ì“°ì´ëŠ” ê³ ìœ í•œ ìŠ¤íƒ€ì¼ì´ë‹¤.

title: Jane Austen ìŠ¤íƒ€ì¼ ë¶„ì„
text:
ë°ì´í„° ì „ì²˜ë¦¬: Austen ë¬¸ì¥ì˜ êµ¬ì¡°í™”

austen <- austen_books() %>%
  group_by(book) %>%
  mutate(chapter = cumsum(str_detect(text, regex("^chapter [\\divxlc]", ignore_case = TRUE)))) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  filter(!str_detect(text, "^\\s*$")) %>%
  filter(chapter != 0) %>%
  filter(!str_detect(text, "^((?i)CHAPTER\\s+[0-9IVXLCDM]+)$")) %>%
  mutate(text = gsub("[[:punct:]]", "", text))

title: Jane Austen ìŠ¤íƒ€ì¼ ë¶„ì„
text:
ì˜¤ìŠ¤í‹´ ë¬¸ì²´ì˜ íŒ¨í„´ì  íŠ¹ì§•
Austen ë¬¸ì¥ì—ì„œ ë°œê²¬ëœ íŠ¹ì§•ì€ ë‹¤ìŒê³¼ ê°™ë‹¤:

ê°ì •ì  ì–´íœ˜ì˜ ë°˜ë³µ: I must confess, I assure you, with all my heart
ë…¼ë¦¬ì  ì—°ê²°ì–´ ì„ í˜¸: therefore, however, nevertheless
ìê¸° ì„œìˆ  í‘œí˜„ ë¹ˆë„: I must, It is


austen_uni <- austen %>%
  unnest_tokens(output = "unigram", input = text, token = "words")

austen_bi <- austen %>%
  unnest_tokens(output = "bigram", input = text, token = "ngrams", n = 2)

bi_count <- austen_bi %>%
  count(bigram, name = "bigram_count", sort = TRUE) %>%
  separate(bigram, c("w1", "w2"), sep = " ") %>%
  filter(if_any(c(w1, w2), ~ !is.na(.))) %>%
  filter(if_all(c(w1, w2), ~ !str_detect(., "^[0-9]")))

bi_probs <- bi_count %>%
  group_by(w1) %>%
  mutate(
    total_after_w1 = sum(bigram_count),
    probability = bigram_count / total_after_w1
  ) %>%
  ungroup() %>%
  arrange(desc(probability))

title: Jane Austen ìŠ¤íƒ€ì¼ ë¶„ì„
text:
N-gram ê¸°ë°˜ ë¬¸ì¥ ìƒì„± ì˜ˆì‹œ

generate_sentence <- function(bigram_probs, start_word = "still", max_len = 15) {
  sentence <- c(start_word)
  current_word <- start_word

  for (i in 1:max_len) {
    candidates <- bigram_probs[bigram_probs$w1 == current_word, ]
    if (nrow(candidates) == 0) break
    next_word <- sample(candidates$w2, size = 1, prob = candidates$probability)
    sentence <- c(sentence, next_word)
    current_word <- next_word
  }
  paste(sentence, collapse = " ")
}

set.seed(4567)
generate_sentence(bi_probs, start_word = "still", max_len = 15)

[1] "still it ought to go i shall only as second glance was not as to join"
